column1: Boguchar (Russian: Богуча́р) is a town and the administrative center of Bogucharsky District in Voronezh Oblast
column3: located on the Boguchar River (a tributary of the Don)
column5: the administrative center of the oblast. Population: 11

column1: Isaac Massa's map of Southern Russia printed in 1638 indicates a settlement near the confluence of the Boguchar River with Don called Bogunar (which is an obvious misspell caused by the similarity of Cyrillic letters ч (ch) and н (n)). However
column2: it is located on a different place than present-day Boguchar
column4: on the left bank of the Don River. This area was inhabited by Don Cossacks in the 17th century
column5: but was devastated during the suppression of the Bulavin Rebellion (1707–08)
column6: in which the upper Don Cossacks were active participants. Afterwards
column7: the area has never been a part of the Don Cossack Host
column8: but rather of Sloboda Ukraine and later Voronezh Governorate
column9: since it was settled by the Ostrogozhsk cossacks of Ukrainian ethnicity in the years 1716–17. The town status was granted to Boguchar in 1779.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Boguchar serves as the administrative center of Bogucharsky District. As an administrative division
column3: it is incorporated within Bogucharsky District as Boguchar Urban Settlement. As a municipal division
column4: this administrative unit also has urban settlement status and is a part of Bogucharsky Municipal District.

column1: The 1st Independent Guards Tank Brigade of the Russian Ground Forces is based here
column3: Western Military District. It was reformed from a storage base in 2015
column4: and carries the heritage of the 10th Guards Tank Corps "Uralsko-Lvovskaya" "Volunteers".
